image.altText: A close-up of OJ Simpson wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: OJ Simpson, the former American football star at the centre of a double-murder trial that gripped the world in the 1990s, dies of cancer.

title.children: OJ Simpson, American footballer accused of ex-wife's murder, dies aged 76

image.altText: A woman wearing a suit and walking outdoors looks at the camera and raises her hand

props.synopsis: Videos of Spanish soccer player Jenni Hermoso sunbaking on a yacht in Ibiza made global headlines in the days after last year's World Cup final in Sydney. Now, court documents filed in Madrid have detailed new allegations about harassment and intimidation in the days that followed.

title.children: The world watched an unwanted kiss. Now court documents have revealed allegations about what happened next

image.altText: An older man in a white shirt and sunglasses stands on his bush property, looking stern

props.synopsis: Bob Horsfall thought the fight was over after the proposal near his Boyanup property was rejected last year, but a revised plan is being reviewed, renewing his concerns.

title.children: Home owners concerned about silica dust from proposed sand mine

image.altText: A Vietnamese woman wearing a white shirt sitting in court flanked by security women.

props.synopsis: Truong My Lan's company was building luxury residential complexes and shopping centres. She's now been sentenced to death.

title.children: Vietnamese property tycoon sentenced to death in $US27 billion fraud case

image.altText: Foreign minister Penny Wong faces the media in Adelaide. 2024-04-06 10:04:00

props.synopsis: Australia's foreign minister urges Iran to "use its influence in the region to promote stability, not to contribute to escalation".

title.children: Australia urges Iran to show restraint as it vows retaliation against Israel

image.altText: A dolphin swims in clear shallow water

props.synopsis: Bunbury's Dolphin Discovery Centre gets a $1.5 million funding boost from the taxpayer after entering voluntary administration in February.

title.children: Popular attraction allowing tourists to feed wild dolphins rescued by funding lifeline

image.altText: The long, slanted nose of a blue, grey and black bullet train sits on a special concrete track wit one metal rail.

props.synopsis: China has the world's fastest train but it wants to push speeds even higher. It has recently run a train through a low-vacuum tube at speeds of more than 600 kph — but the designers want it to ultimately reach a blistering 4,000 kph.

title.children: 'Commuting 400 kms in around half an hour': China's latest maglev development could change how cities work

image.altText: A three-panel collage of Bruce Springsteen, Kiss' Gene Simmons, and Katy Perry

props.synopsis: Superstar artists are selling their rights at blockbuster prices. But who's buying? What's driving this trend? And who benefits?

title.children: From Kiss to Katy Perry, many artists are letting go of their rights. Here's why

image.altText: A group of pedestrians walking along a footpath by the Yarra River on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: The BOM's first winter forecast of 2024 shows most of Australia having both minimum and maximum temperatures of about 1-2 degrees Celsius above average.

title.children: BOM forecasts this winter will be one of Australia's warmest on record

image.altText: Composite image of Kaitlyn Torpey and a guide dog playing with a toy.

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: A Matildas victory, a dazzling solar eclipse and Roger the rescue dog gets to work in Taiwan

image.altText: A graphic with a man in the foreground and wind farms in the background

props.synopsis: Australians will be paying more for energy in the future and they're not yet prepared for that reality, says Alinta CEO Jeff Dimery.

title.children: We were promised cleaner energy would equal cheaper energy. This energy boss says that’s a half-truth

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Fresh data on producer inflation renews hopes that inflation in the US is cooling, sending Wall Street higher after a subdued session, while the Australian share market is set to open lower when trading begins. Follow live.

title.children: Wall Street rallies on inflation optimism, Argentina cuts interest rates to 70pc, ASX to fall

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried appeals fraud conviction and 25-year sentence
Argentina cuts interest rates ... to 70 per cent

image.altText: An edited screengrab of Bluey showing dogs watching tv, where the image on screen is a dog watching Bluey on TV

props.synopsis: Videos of pups watching Bluey — and apparently enjoying it — often circulate on social media, with some suggesting the show's colours are particularly canine-friendly. But is there any science behind the idea?

title.children: Why do dogs love watching Bluey? An expert in animal behaviour has some theories

image.altText: Casuarina Prison drone

props.synopsis: A coronial inquest has heard it's been "impossible" to keep at-risk detainees safe from self-harming at WA's troubled Unit 18 since it was created. WARNING: This story contains the name and image of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: Cleveland Dodd inquest hears nurse's emotional letter to boy's family, calling his death 'complete tragedy'

image.altText: the back of a man's head with traffic lights in the background

props.synopsis: A growing number of Aboriginal people are being struck and killed on Northern Territory roads. Indigenous leaders are sounding the alarm.

title.children: The NT has the highest rate of pedestrian deaths. One in four drivers don't stop

image.altText: The inside of the stadium showing crowds, people on the field and fireworks.

props.synopsis: The 2032 Brisbane Olympics have caused a stir at home over stadium plans but for the International Olympic Committee a higher-stakes game is being played.

title.children: The battle for the future of the Olympic Games is being played out in Brisbane and it's about more than stadiums

image.altText: The Prime Minister stands in a leafy green area holding a press conference

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese's government is defining itself by robust stances, and two totally different topics this week are showing us how.

title.children: After this week, Albanese government can't be accused of being too cautious

image.altText: Nins and Kate stand on the grass in the domain in Sydney in colourful shirts starring at the camera with fierce expressions

props.synopsis: The New South Wales child protection sector is losing more caseworkers than it is employing. The union has launched a month of action calling on the state government to fix staff shortages or continue to put vulnerable children at risk.

title.children: 'You’re caseworker number 24': Staffing shortages mean 'revolving door' of caseworkers in child protection system

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair, wearing a red vest with a 'Save the Children' logo on it. She is standing in front of rubble.

props.synopsis: Aid workers in Gaza say they're "overwhelmed" as humanitarian requests are constantly rejected while famine looms.

title.children: 'Next to nothing to protect aid workers': Aid workers in Gaza say the situation is getting worse

image.altText: Close up of three indigenous comedians performing.

props.synopsis: Ever laughed so loudly the cops came? Emerging comedian Kirsten Lynch says she's had family laughing so hard it's happened twice.

title.children: Making room for Blak comedians at the Melbourne Comedy Festival

image.altText: Construction worker carrying bunch of pipes on shoulder at construction site.

props.synopsis: One in five Australians over 45 live with chronic pain and it can impact every aspect of their lives, including their work life.

title.children: 'They are really in the dark': Why Keith didn't discuss his chronic pain with his workmates

image.altText: Two men stand side-by-side in caps in front of a locked fence gate

props.synopsis: Bunbury locals say they still feel betrayed by the closure of an accessible public jetty, an election commitment by the WA Labor Party.

title.children: Election promise jetty opened at a cost of $457,000 faces permanent closure just four years later

image.altText: A rocket on scaffolding is lifted up on a launch pad.

props.synopsis: It's taken the Gilmour brothers nearly 10 years to build and design a locally made orbital rocket. Space enthusiasts are set to flock to north Queensland to see it lift off.

title.children: Pointed towards the sky, this Australian-first rocket is set to blast a small town into the global spotlight

image.altText: A composite image showing Peter Dutton in a high-vis vest and Anthony Albanese in a rugby jersey.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton was trying to turn the blowtorch on Labor for its handling of the Israel-Gaza war, but his controversial comments left him facing questions instead.

title.children: Dutton sought to turn the blowtorch on Albanese and Wong. He ended up facing his own questions

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks out to the audience, he wears a yellow tie with a suit

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese's set-piece policy announcement on Thursday was not short on ambition, but for now was mostly a re-announcement. What are the prospects of his future made in Australia?

title.children: The PM is heralding the dawn of a new manufacturing era, but it may not be so simple

image.altText: Roxanne Tickle walking into Federal Court

props.synopsis: Transgender woman Roxanne Tickle alleges the CEO of Giggle for Girls ran a two-year "public campaign" against her after being removed from the app.

title.children: CEO ran two-year public campaign against transgender woman after she was removed from app, court told

image.altText: Smoke and fire coming from a building in the distance with more buildings in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Ukraine is warning it is running low on air defence systems, as it calls for more assistance in its two-year war against Russia.

title.children: Kyiv power plant destroyed in Russian missile strike

image.altText: Alcohol bottles on sand

props.synopsis: The NT government opened expressions of interest for the voluntary buy-back of grocery store liquor licences but has so far been unsuccessful striking a deal with Alice Springs operators.

title.children: 'It's an addiction, not a choice': Calls to reduce bottle shops in Alice Springs

image.altText: A monopoly board with every property being a "go to jail"

props.synopsis: Police Commissioner Michael Murphy says he expects more racist material to surface from within the NT Police Force, after reports an image of a "Black Monopoly" board was emailed around the force in 2008.

title.children: NT police commissioner says 'Black Monopoly' email circulated among officers is 'very concerning'

image.altText: A person in a white protective suit stands next to a lake holding a dead crane.

props.synopsis: Australia is one of the last places on the planet free from high pathogenicity bird flu. But authorities warn there's an increased risk of an outbreak here as scientists say the world is in an animal pandemic.

title.children: Bird flu has spread to dairy cows in the US. Here's why the world is watching

image.altText: A player mimics crying as a sledge to another AFL player during a match

props.synopsis: Former Brisbane Lions captain Dayne Zorko says teammate Noah Answerth's mock crying, referencing an ugly incident from 2022, was "not the way we want to win".

title.children: Lion's gesture mocks Petty over crying incident following 2022 sledge

image.altText: Matthew Denny throws a discus in competition

props.synopsis: As they meet for the biggest even on the domestic calendar, Australia's greatest athletes and strongest Paris medal hopes voice their support for World Athletics's move to introduce prize money for Olympic gold medallists.

title.children: At our national champs, Australia's greatest athletes have 3.6 million more reasons to strive for Olympic glory
